Yes! The new update solves my issue, thanks!
zipkin-java 0.13.0 has both scribe and sampler-zookeeper (the adaptive one). there's still probably a week or two's work before 1.0 is realistic.

I think we'll want to bump this out as a repo, still, especially as versions are being cut quickly due to UI fixies that have nothing to do with the scala code. If we did, we could even adjust docker to be able to pull the UI into the server separately. This has the advantage of making UI updates decoupled from server code updates. cc @eirslett @abesto

Given that we're (probably) retiring the Scala code anyways, maybe the UI module can live with zipkin-java? (It stays in this repository openzipkin/zipkin, while the java code is moved from openzipkin/zipkin-java to openzipkin/zipkin)
yeah that could work, too

This is a side effect of gradle. You'll notice that the server logged that
it started. Ignore the 97%, basically

neat idea. One way could be to save them off to a user profile (even
browser storage), since traces are so small. Ex,
zipkin/api/v1/trace/trace_id becomes searchable locally. Just an idea.

PS this is only an issue in cassandra at the moment, since others don't
support TTLs anyway. It might be tricky to do this on the storage side
portably, since we don't have a portable feature for TTL. That doesn't
preclude custom logic, just explanation.

Since the UI has been decoupled from the server side, another possible solution is to have a Save As, so that the user can save the trace json as a file on local disk and later load it into the UI. It's especially useful considering that tracing ultimately is used to troubleshoot perf issues, so one could save a trace, attach it to a ticket, and someone else can later load the trace and see it in the UI.

We already have the JSON button, so Save As is there, but we don't have a Load function in the UI.

> We already have the JSON button, so Save As is there, but we don't have a
> Load function in the UI.
> 
> "We" are a privileged minority until #1060 :P
huh, I didn't realize, thought it was in already.
Are you sure the trace is in the database?
i use 'SELECT \* from traces where trace_id=21757' in cassandra,  i can find 2 rows, so i input 21717 in traces, but not find anything

21717 or 21757?
I'm not sure what the problem could be, you could try starting zipkin-server locally and step-through-debug it, maybe?

Yes, it looks correct.
Which instrumentation library are you using? Brave? Finagle? Pyramid? Usually, the trace IDs are 64-bit hex-encoded numbers, 21757 is a very small number! I don't think it's related though.
i use Brave, but 21757 is myself input , not brave generate, i read brave is a random long, 21757 maybe also is random long, i read brave code again, thanks very much
i use String s = IdConversion.convertToString(21757);   result is 54fd, and input 54fd to trace, i can get result, thanks very much

Hi, Sarah.

Thanks for proposing this. Before we start, the scala server is on the way out and this is a fairly sweeping change. To review and merge this would take take effort away from finishing the server transition, and still require us to do it again there. Any chance we can implement it there in zipkin-java first place? I'd offer to help.

update.

https://github.com/openzipkin/docker-zipkin
note.. the test case for any variant of this implementation would be to not only look at the locally published pom, but also run `./gradlew cleanIdea idea` and ensure it doesn't crash
If this ends up working (it seems to), a custom version might work to selectively prune just scala deps from zipkin-cassandra-core https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/pull/1106
test will be if the snapshot building now has a pom stripped of deps or not.. http://oss.jfrog.org/artifactory/oss-snapshot-local/io/zipkin/zipkin-ui/1.39.8-SNAPSHOT/
pom worked.. cutting a patch release to fix the deps
Done! Thanks!

Hi @adriancole! Thanks for looking at the PR :)

I know it can be difficult to complete a migration when folks are still adding features to legacy code.  Since I am more familiar with Scala than Java and I already have a system that uses this scala version, I figured this was a good place for me to add & test the feature.

I'd be happy to work on this feature in the zipkin-java version! Is that really a blocker for addressing this in scala?

> I'd be happy to work on this feature in the zipkin-java version! Is that
> really a blocker for addressing this in scala?
> 
> Hi, sarah, it is mostly a matter of time and attention, particularly as the
> impact of the slice query thing is hard to grok sometimes. Also anorm is a
> royal pain and usually any time it is touched == an hour lost on some weird
> thing.

As long as you don't mind doing revisions until tests on all that backends,
and sharing the pain during that, I don't mind supporting by looking into
it and giving advice.

here's a hint. cassandra tests run when it is already running on localhost. If you start it similar to how travis runs (or start it however you like), you can get tests to fail locally instead of only in travis 

https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/blob/master/.travis.yml#L12
added this which might help us collaborate. Ex I can steal ideas from you, and in the case I figure something out, pitch them back https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin-java/issues/182

My advice would be to add a new test case to `SpanStoreSpec` that can smoke out issues around sliceQuery and priority. By running this directly, you might find issues faster.

Here's an idea:

make 2 timestamps
make 10 endpoints (with different serviceNames)
store 20 single-span traces that vary on above. Ex. 10 traces have one timestamp and another 10 have the other

query the span store with serviceName=None and limit 10. You should see one of each serviceName, and only the most recent timestamp.

query the span store with serviceName=None, limit 10, and endTs before the more recent timestamp, but after the less recent one. You should see one of each serviceName, and only the less recent timestamp.

Hi. so the docs actually indicate a megabyte is the max size per message.
Regardless, let me see if there's a way for us to constrain this portably.
If would be nice if we could have one collector parameter for this, as
large messages can become problematic.

http://kafka.apache.org/documentation.html

lgtm

any particular new feature you are after?

Sorry I should have mentioned. Mainly this is maintenance, ie not falling
too far behind. Also there's supposedly a performance improvement. I'll
check logs to see if that helped at all.
performance has been erradic in general, so this might not change things on that note.

which reporter are you using to send the messages? I noticed that htrace compresses the messages like so..

https://github.com/apache/incubator-htrace/blob/master/htrace-zipkin/src/main/java/org/apache/htrace/impl/KafkaTransport.java#L105

so kafka is tuned for smaller message sizes, and 1MB with compression can hold a fair amount of spans. Can you try compression first? I've opened an issue in zipkin-java to add metrics on message size https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin-java/issues/165

Our reporter sends message less than 1MB (I have stats to ensure that). But the kafka server's configuration is 200MB (other message needs this)ï¼Œand the config seems to be global and affects our topic.
OK if that's the case, then this needs to be a kafka-specific parameter, not conflated with span message size
reverting this. Even with latest idea, the project no longer imports properly. will rev-lock for now.
ok so maybe `KAFKA_FETCH_MESSAGE_MAX_BYTES` for lack of a better idea..
Yeah.

here's the related change in zipkin-java https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin-java/pull/185

Note: I've left travis alone, which makes sure we still work with old cassandra
ok np

It's hard to compensate for by squeezing the trace together horizontally - we don't know on beforehand how wide the text will be... (we could use a heuristic maybe)
One can always drag a box around 5 spans on the right to zoom in.

Ok I added another test and fixed the currently failing tests. My cassandra queries still seem pretty bad. For getTraceIdsByAnnotation I don't think it's even possible to do in a single query since the binary annotations include serviceName

If the beginning of the span is more than half-way (or two-thirds) through the trace the text can be aligned to be on the the left side of the span.

Super simple, huge win on trace pages like the screenshot above, which I have heaps of!

I think mck's solution is quite elegant, and not too hard to implement.
We'll have to adjust the traceDataToMustache function (or what it's called) to have logic for start ts (in percentage) and set "span_text_class" to either "span-text-left" or "span-text-right". And we also need a corresponding CSS change.
I've ran into this too -- and the common thread for mine seems to be that they are missing the core annotations (cs, sr, et al).

As a new user, I'm adding zipkin to my system because I _don't_ know what my system is doing underneath the hood. Chances are, because the system architecture isn't managed at all (complex political problem...), it's not a DAG.

There are also a couple of other "valid" cases for not having a DAG, for example, at FINN.no we have something like this:

varnish -> finn.no -> varnish -> api -> database

The underlying Spark job doesn't assume a DAG, that's only our UI. So we could rewrite it with another JavaScript library than dagre/d3, but it would take some work. (PRs welcome, I suppose?)

The discussion is etching away from original topic, but afaik there is no restriction on the architecture diagram to be a DAG, e.g. below there are bidirectional dependencies. 
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3523016/15193145/6c9d26be-178a-11e6-88ef-6a3fd98bd3cb.png)

It does happen sometimes, I'm not sure why. Dagre is DAG-specific: https://github.com/cpettitt/dagre
Maybe the behavior is undetermined when you provide a cyclic graph...

Anyways, the UI won't break entirely if you have cycles! It's just that the rendering library is originally meant for DAGs.

The zipkin ui is tuned for zipkin annotations, so if you aren't logging any zipkin annotations, they won't show up. We have tests to show that if zipkin annotations are logged, a service name will be chosen. 

https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/blob/master/zipkin-ui/test/component_ui/traceSummary.test.js

First thing is to correct your instrumentation to log a zipkin annotation (like "sr"), or a [special zipkin binary annotation](https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/blob/master/zipkin-thrift/src/main/thrift/com/twitter/zipkin/zipkinCore.thrift#L199) ("ca", "sa" or "lc").

You can validate your data by changing the url into an api call. ex. http://host:9411/api/v1/trace/hex-encoded-id returns the json

Yes, that's a "bug" (or feature, if you want) in jQuery. If it encounters a string that looks a bit like JSON, it will parse it as JSON and end up with an object instead of a string.
The fix would be to force the message to be parsed as a string. I'm not sure exactly where in the UI code it happens.
@adriancole are there unit tests for what gets displayed in the UI?

yeap formatEndpoint has unit tests in traceToMustache.test.js

probably, just test that passing blank has the intended effect. Also I suspect the callsite needs to be updated to actually pass serviceName, right? Otherwise it is dead code.

zipkin-java is headed towards the finish line, we've had no unresolved objections, and a dozen votes in favor.

I think we should focus on logistics at this point, for example explicitly suggest new projects and those with flexibility to use zipkin-java, mention more formally the bug-fix nature of this project, make explicit logistics of non-scala assets such as the thrift files and javascript. Mention the current plan which is to replace master with the assets that are currently in the zipkin-java repo. Setup an answer for the question of who's already using it, etc.

To do all this, we could either re-title/ repurpose this, or close it and make a new logistics issue. Any other ideas?

PS here's latest release notes from the java project: https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin-java/releases/tag/0.20.0

reproduced by uploading a test span and looking at trace 1

``` bash
$ curl -s -X POST -H 'Content-Type: application/json' localhost:9411/api/v1/spans -d '[{"traceId":"1","name":"bang","id":"2","timestamp":1234,"duration":100,"binaryAnnotations":[{"key":"json","value":"{\"msg\":{\"detail\":\"foo\"}}","endpoint":{"serviceName":"flintstones","ipv4":"127.0.0.1"}}]}]'
$ open http://localhost:9411/traces/1
```
fooling around here: https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/blob/master/zipkin-ui/js/component_ui/spanPanel.js#L37

@yurishkuro @eirslett fyi, this class doesn't have a test yet, and usually it takes several hours for me to refactor things until they are testable with my current experience level. Your call whether to merge with manual testing or not. I've manually tested with below, and also tested old annotations don't get quoted.

``` bash
$ curl -s -X POST -H 'Content-Type: application/json' localhost:9411/api/v1/spans -d '[{"traceId":"1","name":"bang","id":"2","timestamp":1234,"duration":100,"binaryAnnotations":[{"key":"json","value":"{\"msg\":{\"detail\":\"foo\"}}","endpoint":{"serviceName":"flintstones","ipv4":"127.0.0.1"}}]}]'
$ open http://localhost:9411/traces/1
```

oh I remember this issue! We discussed and performed no action on this in the past.

Last time we discussed this, we noted that having endpoint information for binary annotations isn't something we expect to carry forward in the model.

Making a UI change to special case when multiple services report the same value formalizes a feature that will look "missing" when we finally get time to fix the model to disallow this.

Next time you are raising an issue we have discussed and took no action on, please make reference to the former discussion and mention what has changed which would lead to us taking different action now.
closing this as the issue itself hasn't changed https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/issues/989

FYI current workaround when people are sending the same key from multiple services is to look at the json. Looking at the json will be easier if anyone implements the json button https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/issues/1060

Here's some thoughts about choices we can make besides closing this issue.

### Display service name in binary annotations knowing what we know

We have discussed this issue, and know that many instrumentation projects dodge duplicating binary annotation key/value pairs in the same span. We also know the model won't likely support multimaps with endpoints in the future. We could choose to make this change, inverting the UI element to showing more detail as opposed to less, eventhough we know the constraints of this.

If we did something like this, we should explicitly agree. For example, multiple people. When it gets to implementation, we should make the UI element consistent, either by emulating the style of annotation rows, or changing the style of annotation rows. For this reason, we should be careful to review pull requests carefully. Ex. Incomplete screen shots can hide inconsistency.

### Make it easier to fork the UI

The UI no longer has any scala dependency etc. This particular change is not the only one that sites may want to customize. For example, they may want to change the titles, favicons etc. Rather than making everyone see an edge case, we can encourage forks, possibly by moving the UI into a separate repo. When we work in such a model, it means we can delay loaded topics like this until they become more widely requested.

### your idea here

this PR is unrelated to that discussion. It is here to display service name normally encoded in SA/CA/LC, which is otherwise hidden (LC had a special handling, which with this PR becomes unnecessary). The service name in the SA/CA annotations is respected in other parts of the code, specifically in the logic that derives a single service name for a span: https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/blob/master/zipkin-ui/js/component_ui/traceSummary.js#L53
@yurishkuro you're right. re-opened and changing the title as this is related to "address" annotations, which are special-cased.
lgtm

Ps can you put in a shot of the whole span detail element? It would be
easier to tell what the result looks like (ex if we are still consistent)
